displayed_text: Doctor: Hi. How are you? Doctor: You’re in pain. Why don’t you go and talk to your girlfriend and get your pain medicine from her? Patient: I’ve can’t did that. Doctor: You what? Patient: It ain’t no girlfriend. Doctor: Or whoever that was. The woman. Patient: So that be ah ah the police looking for her and now they found and press charges. I don’t know her number. I don’t want her around me. I want nobody around me no more. Doctor: hhh Okay because… Patient: I don’t want no one… Doctor: …you know what the pharmacist said now. Patient: Yes I’ve been going to H_____. Doctor: So you’re going to H_____ Pharmacy now? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home. Patient: Oh well- Doctor: And the same next week, same thing. So you always stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But they’ll cover that cost. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Okay, so we’ll do that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And uh I want to see you in three months. Patient: Um hmm. How’s the blood. Doctor: Oh PSA. That’s the most important. Undetectable no evidence of any cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I mean really undetectable and we have to because a part of yours went into the seminal vesicle- Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: -we had to be very careful about following up on it because there’s a slight risk that it may reoccur, so we’ll follow it and follow it very carefully. Patient: I’ve been trying eat right, I’ve been trying to eat stuff, you know I’ve been trying to do my own you know like doing research and stuff that’s good for me. Doctor: Good. That’s good.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All that sugar stuff, all the rocket fuel—it’s all myth. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Right, it’s all myth. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know you can eat red meat once a week. You can drink you know in moderation. Do not ruin - you know it’s all myth, right. People feel very strongly about those myths. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We removed it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it was going into it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then the question is, did it go from there elsewhere? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that’s what we’re following. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right now, there is no evidence that it has gone any place else in your body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But we’ll continue to follow that.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there. Doctor: Okay, that's fine. Let me print this out for you so that you can see what I'm talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll print both of them. Because the way that we, oh no there’s a lot of stuff coming out. So let me first sort of describe what we call like the stages of prostate cancer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: I’ll use the back of this. I think we talked about this last time, but I'll just, if I'm repeating myself and you get it, just say I remember all of this. So stages, so first you have what we call localized. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh. (pause) Patient: Right. Doctor: That it’s clear that this isn’t helping you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, we could say, “No, let’s move on.” I can give you the, uh, consent forms. But, if you already know, that I don’t want to do chemotherapy, I know I’m not going to come in here. The consent form does explain chemotherapy. So, that’s something that you’d be entertaining as a next step, whether it be here or locally.

Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. Yes after the first six to eight weeks. Family Member: But that’s a few months down the road. Patient: And you’d maintain the care? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s very important. Patient: Okay and uh okay. Yeah we’ll look at the consent form. It sounds more complicated. Doctor: Because one side, yeah so there is – I think what I’ll do is I’ll give you the consent to read through and then we’ll set up a time to come in downtown with the potential for doing all the testing needed if you decide you’re okay with proceeding. Patient: And we were planning to go on a cruise in February. Doctor: Okay. That should be fine still.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes. Doctor: And you know that’s just a miserable status Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: to be in so we have to have you take over-the-counter um stool softeners, MiraLAX, so kind of almost like oh, I took two of these I maybe have to see where my poop situation is, Patient: Right. Doctor: I might need to take MiraLAX twice or I might have to add MiraLAX to Senokot or you go down the poop aisle at Rite Aid or CVS Patient: Right.

Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: It’s pretty strong. Doctor: I like that better and less addictive than Ambien. Family Member 1: Oh, okay. Okay, questions. My one daughter is pregnant. Then we watch her her little two year old. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: About three times a week.

Family Member: Oh yeah. Doctor: The garage I’m not evening tackling. Family Member: The basement. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah same thing. (Laughs) Family Member: Good luck. Doctor: Good luck is right. Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do… Doctor: No, no you’re probably gonna stay here and S__ will take you over because those are special tubes that she has to send out and all that. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And would it be possible for me to have copies of that stuff? Doctor: Yeah I thought you might I know you usually want some. This is the bone scan. Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that?

Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah. Doctor: Maybe it will cool down a little bit. Patient: Yeah right, yeah. Doctor: But let’s not do it too fast because remember even before this when we tried to get you off of it… Patient: Yeah I had issues. Doctor: You had a major revolt. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s sorta breaking through, right? You’re cancer’s already sort of figured out how it works. Patient: Right. Doctor: You’re options are A different standard of care pill, but we worry that if you go from that pill to the other pill, we don’t get a lot of mileage out of that because it’s too similar. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So then we could talk about chemo. (Pause) Patient: Okay. You heard about this cancer pen? Doctor: - no one’s gotten a rash and all that. Patient: - you heard about this cancer pen that they came up with? Doctor: You know how many cancer pills that are out? Patient: No, a pen! Pen! Doctor: Pen?
